snippet: The appraisal by the defense secretary and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff reflected increased concern about the uprising in Syria, in which more than 7,500 people have reportedly been killed.
abstract: Gen Martin E Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Defense Secretary Leon E Panetta testify before Senate Armed Services Committee that Pres Obama has asked for preliminary military options in Syria; they emphasize the risks but say that the administration still believes that diplomatic and economic pressure is the best way to protect Syria from Bashar al-Assad's government repression.

byline.original: By ELISABETH BUMILLER and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Elisabeth Bumiller reported from Washington, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Neil MacFarquhar, Hwaida Saad and an employee of The New York Times from Beirut, Lebanon, Edward Wong from Beijing, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: The appraisal by the defense secretary and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff reflected increased concern about the uprising in Syria, in which more than 7,500 people have reportedly been killed.

headline.seo: Senior U.N. Official Due in Syria as Forces Scramble to Scrub Signs of Assault
headline.main: Top Pentagon Officials Stress Risks in Syria
headline.print_headline: Top Pentagon Officials Stress Risks in Syria
